leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [300,100] s 89 Power of Court to modify or extinguish easements and restrictive covenants

leg:heading.title: Power of Court to modify or extinguish easements and restrictive covenants

p.text: Where land is subject to an easement or a profit à prendre or to a restriction or an obligation arising under covenant or otherwise as to the user thereof, the Court may from time to time, on the application of any person interested in the land, by order modify or wholly or partially extinguish the easement, profit à prendre, restriction or obligation upon being satisfied—

that by reason of change in the user of any land having the benefit of the easement or restriction, or in the character of the neighbourhood or other circumstances of the case which the Court may deem material, the easement or restriction ought to be deemed obsolete, or that the continued existence thereof would impede the reasonable user of the land subject to the easement or restriction without securing practical benefit to the persons entitled to the easement or profit à prendre or to the benefit of the restriction or obligation, or would, unless modified, so impede such user; or

that the persons of the age of eighteen years or upwards and of full capacity for the time being or from time to time entitled to the easement or profit à prendre or to the benefit of the restriction, whether in respect of estates in fee simple or any lesser estates or interests in the land to which the easement, the profit à prendre or the benefit of the restriction is annexed, have agreed to the easement or restriction being modified or wholly or partially extinguished, or by their acts or omissions may reasonably be considered to have abandoned the easement or profit à prendre wholly or in part or waived the benefit of the restriction wholly or in part;
in the case of an obligation—

that the prescribed authority entitled to the benefit of the obligation has agreed to the obligation's being modified or wholly or partially extinguished or by its acts or omissions may reasonably be considered to have waived the benefit of the obligation wholly or in part; or
that the obligation has become unreasonably expensive or unreasonably onerous to perform when compared with the benefit of its performance to the authority; or
that the proposed modification or extinguishment will not substantially injure the persons entitled to the easement or profit à prendre, or to the benefit of the restriction or obligation.
[subs (1) am Act 60 of 1970 Sch 1 ; Act 70 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

For the purposes of subsection (1)(b) , an easement may be treated as abandoned if the Court is satisfied that the easement has not been used for at least 20 years before the application under subsection (1) is made.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 17 of 2009 Sch 2[2], effective 13 May 2009 ]

Where any proceedings are instituted to enforce an easement, profit à prendre, restriction or obligation or to enforce any rights arising out of a breach of any restriction, any person against whom the proceedings are instituted may in such proceedings apply to the Court for an order under this section.
[subs (2) am Act 52 of 1970 Sch 2 (as by am Act 41 of 1972 Sch 2) ; Act 70 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

The Court may on the application of any person interested make an order declaring whether or not in any particular case any land is affected by an easement, profit à prendre, restriction or obligation, and the nature and extent thereof, and whether the same is enforceable, and if so by whom.
[subs (3) am Act 70 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]
[subs (4) am Act 52 of 1970 Sch 2 (as by am Act 41 of 1972 Sch 2) ; Act 70 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1S ; Act 11 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]

An order under this section that is registered in accordance with this section is binding on persons (whether or not of full age or capacity and whether or not such persons are parties to the proceedings or have been served with notice) who:
are, or become, entitled to the easement or profit à prendre or interested in enforcing the restriction or obligation, and
have, or obtain, an estate or interest in the land burdened by the easement, profit à prendre, restriction or obligation.
[subs (5) subst Act 17 of 2009 Sch 2[3], effective 13 May 2009 ]
This section applies to easements, profit à prendre and restrictions existing at the commencement of the Conveyancing (Amendment) Act 1930 , or coming into existence after such commencement.
[subs (6) am Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

An order under this section affecting land not under the provisions of the Real Property Act 1900 , may be registered in the General Register of Deeds. No such order shall release or bind any land until it is so registered.
[subs (7) am Act 17 of 1972 s 7 ; Act 57 of 1992 s 3 and Sch ]

This section applies to land under the provisions of the Real Property Act 1900 , and the Registrar-General shall, on application made in the form approved under that Act, make all necessary recordings in the Register kept under that Act for giving effect to the order.

For the purposes of this subsection, a grant, certificate of title or duplicate registered dealing that is not in the possession of the Registrar-General shall be deemed to be wrongfully retained within the meaning of section 136 of the Real Property Act 1900.
[subs (8) subst Act 17 of 1972 s 7]
In the case of land which is not under the provisions of the Real Property Act 1900 , a memorandum of such order shall be endorsed on such of the instruments of title as the Court directs.
[subs (9) am Act 17 of 1972 s 7 ; Act 70 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]
[s 89 subst Act 44 of 1930 s 19]
